title: üá≥üá± 2023 Dutch Election Dashboard
text:
Methodology
In collaboration with Who Targets Me, we monitored 1071 political advertisers in Netherlands during the 2023 Dutch parliamentary election to better understand how campaigns use different targeting methods made available by Meta. To do this, we used data from the Meta Ad Library, using the new ‚ÄòAudience‚Äô data which gives some detail on how pages target their ads.
To better understand the election, we kept only advertisers who:

Advertised in the last 7 days (Oct 24th - Oct 30th 2023)
Advertised in the last 30 days (Oct 1st - Oct 30th 2023)







Note



Meta only provides 7, 30 and 90 days windows for the targeting data in their Ad Library. Meta‚Äôs data also lags by a few days. Report will be updated as soon as new data is available.


For Google platforms, data accessed via the Google Transparency Report provides spending on how much money was spent by parties. In order to fit the Meta ranges, we also show the last seven and 30 days.






Disclaimer



The data shown in this dashboard is based on the platform‚Äôs respective ad libraries which are known to be sometimes incomplete (Edelson et al.¬†2020; Silva et al.¬†2020). For this reason the data shown here might not reflect the full picture nor all political ads that were targeted at voters.




About the Creator of the Dashboard











Fabio Votta is a Postdoc at the University of Amsterdam who studies (online) political microtargeting and its usage around the world.











Want to see how political parties target you? Sign up at Who Targets Me and download the gratis browser plugin to see how parties on Facebook use your data:
https://whotargets.me/







Want to retrieve targeting data from the Facebook Ad Library yourself? This dashboard is powered by the R package: metatargetr. Check it out here:
https://github.com/favstats/metatargetr




Election Targeting Dashboards
A list of election dashboards:

üá≥üá± 2021 Dutch parliamentary election (15th-17th March 2021)
üá©üá™ 2021 German federal election (26 September 2021)
üá∏üá™ 2022 Swedish general election (11th September 2022)
üá∫üá∏ 2022 United States midterm elections (8th November 2022)
üá∫üá∏ 2022 United States midterm elections - Georgia Runoff (6th December 2022)
üáÆüáπ 2023 Lazio & Lombardy regional election (12-13th February 2023)
üá™üá™ 2023 Estonian parliamentary election (5th March 2023)
üá≥üá± 2023 Dutch provincial elections (15th March 2023)
üá≤üá™ 2023 Montenegrin presidential elections (19th March 2023) - 1st round
üá¶üá∫ 2023 New South Wales state election (25th March 2023)
üá´üáÆ 2023 Finnish parliamentary election (2 April 2023)
üáπüá∑ 2023 Turkish general election (14 May 2023) - Round 1
üá©üá™ 2023 Bremen State election (14 May 2023)
üá¨üá∑ 2023 Greek Legislative election (21 May 2023)
üáπüá∑ 2023 Turkish Presidential election (14 May 2023) - Round 2

üá≥üáø 2023 New Zealand general election (14 October 2023)

title: Blog

title: Spending
text: This section shows total and daily spending of political parties in the run-up to the 2023 Dutch parliamentary election for the latest available data.

title: Spending per Targeting Criteria
text:
This section shows spending per targeting criteria used by political parties to reach citizens in the run-up to the 2023 Dutch parliamentary election for the latest available data. It only includes targeting on Meta platforms (Facebook and Instagram), which offers the most detailed targeting options to political advertisers.

How much did campaigns spend on different targeting methods? The graphs below show spending overall across all parties and by party.

Note: targeting criteria can overlap so the percentages do not sum up to 100%.


Oct 1st - Oct 30th 2023 (Last 30 days)Oct 24th - Oct 30th 2023 (Last 7 days)



OverallBy Party








































































































OverallBy Party

title: Targeting
text:
Top Targeted (Detailed) Audiences
Here, we show the top targeted audiences for each party for the ‚Äúdetailed‚Äù targeting that Meta offers (ranked by amount of Euro spend). Most (but not all) of these audiences are ‚Äúinterest‚Äù audiences, i.e.¬†the parties targeted people interested in ‚ÄúBooks‚Äù or ‚ÄúPolitics‚Äù.

title: Targeting
text:
Geographical Exclusion
On Meta, political parties can also exclude certain geographical units. The graphs below show which locations were excluded from seeing political advertisements and how much money the parties spend on these ads. The bigger the area the more money was spend on ads excluding this location.

title: Detailed Audiences

Here, we show the top most contested audiences, i.e.¬†where all parties have spent considerable amounts of money competing to reach voters with the same interests.

title: Location
text:
Geographical Exclusion
On Meta, political parties can also exclude certain geographical units. The graphs below show which locations were excluded from seeing political advertisements and how much money the parties spend on these ads.

Oct 1st - Oct 30th 2023 (Last 30 days)



Postal CodesProvincesCities


The graphs below shows postal code exclusion that parties engaged in on Meta platforms.

CDA













The bigger the area the more money was spend on ads excluding this location.
